unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: P-value of a 2-sided Test Given z-score
question_text:
A significance test was used to test the null hypothesis ${ H }_{ 0 }$: $p=0.20$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }$: $p≠0.20$. The resulting test statistic is $z=-1.73$.
The p-value for this test is approximately
solution:
Since the alternative includes $≠$ we are dealing with a 2 sided test, meaning we are looking for the sum of the probabilities of $z < -1.73$ and $z>1.73$.

Method 1: Solving by using the Standard Normal Distribution Chart

Looking at the z-score table find the probability that $z<-1.73$. This gives a probability of $0.0418$. Now double that probability since the test is 2 sided. The resulting probability of $0.0836$.

Method 2: Using the TI Graphing Calculator

Using the normalcdf function(located by hitting 2nd Vars).
$2*normalcdf(-99999,-1.73,0,1)=0.0836$

Below is the calculator input on the TI-84. Since we are dealing with z-scores the mean is $0$ and standard deviation is $1$. We want our lower value to be a very small number so that is why it is $-99999$.

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'A' is incorrect as this represents the p-value in one of two cases. The first case would be $z<-1.73$. The second case would be $z>1.73$. Choice 'B' is incorrect as this is the average of $0.0836$ and $0.0418$. Choice 'D' is incorrect as this is the probability for $-1.73\le z\le 1.73$. Choice 'E' is incorrect as this represents the p-value in one of two cases. The first case would be $z>-1.73$. The second case would be $z<-1.73$.
